inference:
Solution:
Triangle $JKL$ is a 30-60-90 triangle.  The ratio of the lengths of the sides of a 30-60-90 triangle is $1:\sqrt{3}:2$, so $JL=20$ and $JK=20\sqrt{3}$.  The area of a triangle is $\frac{1}{2}\cdot\text{base}\cdot\text{height}$, so the area of triangle $JKL$ is $\frac{1}{2}\cdot 20\cdot 20\sqrt{3}=\boxed{200\sqrt{3}}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We have $\angle K = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - 60^\circ = 30^\circ$, so $JKL$ is a 30-60-90 triangle. Since $\overline{JL}$ is opposite the $30^\circ$ angle, we have $JL = KL/2 = 10$.  Since $\overline{JK}$ is opposite the $60^\circ$ angle, we have $JK = JL\sqrt{3} = 10\sqrt{3}$.  Therefore, \[[JKL] = \frac{(JK)(JL)}{2} = \frac{(10\sqrt{3})(10)}{2} = \boxed{50\sqrt{3}}.\]
